questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer has started to configure a router for secure remote access as shown. All users who require network access need to be authenticated by the SSH protocol. Which two actions must the engineer implement to complete the SSH configuration? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
B: I assume the access-list 100 does not exist yet, hence all traffic should accepted.
C: login local is configures, so authentication is based on AAA/local users and not a password under line vty.
E: Only ensures, the passwords of type 7 are "encrypted" in the configuration.

So I assume A and D is correct, even though this I also 100% correct in my opinion. SSH key can be configured with a label, so the domain name is not needed.
crypto key generate rsa modulus 2048 label SSH_KEY

Selected Answer: AD
There are four steps required to enable SSH support on a Cisco IOS router:
Configure the hostname command.
Configure the DNS domain.
Generate the SSH key to be used.
Enable SSH transport support for the virtual type terminal (vtys).
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security-vpn/secure-shell-ssh/4145-ssh.html

To enable SSH you need to configure IP domain name + generate crypto keys
So A & D are correct in my choice. 
B is wrong because you do not need an ACL to enable port 22 for SSH
C is wrong because when you have login local you do no need a pass under VTY 
and E is totally out of the scope of the question it is another thing
I think it should be A and D. if you don`t have an ip domain-name you cannot connect using ssh.

comments.content: I guess is B and D, coz you can access via ssh without "ip domain-name"

choices.C: Configure a password under the vty lines.
choices.B: Configure ACL 100 to permit access to port 22.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Sensor Path
The sensor path describes a YANG path or a subset of data definitions in a YANG model with a container. In a YANG model, the sensor path can be specified to end at any level in the container hierarchy.

An MDT-capable device, such as a router, associates the sensor path to the nearest container path in the model. The router encodes and streams the container path within a single telemetry message. A receiver receives data about all the containers and leaf nodes at and below this container path.


Subscription
A subscription binds one or more sensor paths and destinations. An MDT-capable device streams data for each sensor path at the configured frequency (cadence-based streaming) or when the sensor-path content changes (event-based streaming) to the destination.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/optical/ncs1001/telemetry/guide/b-telemetry-cg-ncs1000/core-components-model-driven-telemetry-streaming.html#id_36300

Selected Answer: A
The sensor path is where you configure what you want to send.
This blog isn't from Cisco, but it was written by a former Cisco employee while he worked there. He describes the Sensor Path with the exact wording from this question.

https://xrdocs.io/telemetry/tutorials/2017-10-25-ncs1002-telemetry-deep-dive/

comments.content:
Great info!

“Sensor path”. Describes the data you want your Router to stream to a collector.

“Transport protocol”. Describes the protocol you want to use to deliver the info.

“Encoder”. Describes the format of the data on the wire (for example, GPB).

“Initialization of streaming session”. Describes who initiates the streaming of data (dial-in or dial-out).

“Subscription”. Binds everything together for the router to start streaming data on the configured intervals.

questions.question_text: Which core component of MDT describes the data that an MDT-capable device streams to a collector?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
The question is about the MPLS Lite AKA Unified MPLS, and for that, these two options need to be done.

comments.content:
BGP PIC is for fast recovery on backup links (route) .. core only has 2 routers.. can you explain?
RFC 3107 also has northing to do with Fast recovery.. can you also explain ur answer?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
For 50ms failover BGP PIC is required (BFD as well, but it is not mentioned.)

comments.content: RFC 3107 is actually BGP-LU, which is an essential element of Seamless mpls. which may or may not involve VPNv4. PIC is needed for fast 50 ms convergence. I would go with AE.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
RFC 3107 is Inter-AS Option C. A and C are the answers for this solution.
Seamless mpls with RR inline and VPNV4 between PE's

Questions like these are why ExamTopics exists. PIC core is not listed on the SPCOR blueprint. It's listed on the CCIE-SP blueprint. This question is out of scope for the SPCOR according to Cisco, but I had it on my failed exam attempt yesterday.

comments.content: PIC core is one of the answers because the question asks for "service recovery up to 50 ms". So you have to know that PIC core is used to improve the convergence time.

Not sure if question have anything to do with PIC core though.. PIC core has to do with failure.. but u are right.. Cisco is notorious for throwing off center with badly worded questions and vague MCQ's that have no relevance to real world scenarios..
... but, hey ho.. they run the shop

choices.E: Implement BGP PIC core functionality on routers R2 and R3.
choices.D: Configure three OSPF areas, with Area 0 in the core domain, and Areas 2 and 3 in the aggregation domain.
choices.A: Implement BGP inline RR functionality with next-hop-self capabilities on routers R2 and R3.
choices.B: Implement the IS-IS routing protocol on the access domain.
choices.C: Implement BGP connectivity between routers R1 and R4 with VPNv4 address family enabled.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Tier 1 ISP A purchased several Tier 2 ISPs to increase their customer base and provide more regional coverage. ISP A plans to implement MPLS services in the access layer, with scalability up to 100,000 devices in one packet network and service recovery up to 50 ms. The network architect decided to use different independent IGP and LDP domains and interconnect LSPs that are based on RFC 3107. Which two actions must the network engineer perform to meet the requirements? (Choose two.)

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Tier 1 ISP A is connected to small Tier 3 ISP B. The EBGP routing protocol is used for route exchange. The networking team at ISP A noticed the flapping of BGP sessions with ISP B. The team decides to improve stability on the network by suppressing the subnet for 30 minutes when a session begins to flap. Which action must the team perform to meet this goal?

choices.C: Implement a BGP route-penalty timer on ISP A router R1 with the bgp penalty-timer 30 250 750 15 command.
choices.D: Implement BGP route suppression on ISP A router R2 with the bgp suppression 30 600 1200 30 command.
choices.A: Implement BGP route dampening on ISP A router R1 with the bgp dampening 15 700 1500 30 command.
choices.B: Implement a BGP route withdraw-delay timer on ISP B router R3 with the bgp withdraw-delay 30 15 90 30 command.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer : A > BGP route dampening is used to suppress unstable (flapping) routes. In this case, the command bgp dampening 15 700 1500 30 sets the following parameters:
15: Half-life (time in minutes before penalties are reduced by half).
700: Suppress penalty threshold. Once this threshold is exceeded, the route is suppressed.
1500: Reuse penalty threshold. When the route's penalty falls below this value, it is reused (unsuppressed).
30: Maximum duration (in minutes) for which the route is suppressed.
This configuration meets the requirement of suppressing a route for 30 minutes if flapping occurs.

questions.question_text: How is RSVP used with MPLS traffic engineering tunnels?

choices.A: It assigns a tag to a packet as it travels through the tunnel.
choices.B: It removes and reassigns an MPLS label when the packet enters the tunnel.
choices.C: It reserves bandwidth along the path of the tunnel.
choices.D: It reduces the CPU burden when a packet travels through the tunnel.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Answer : C > RSVP (Resource Reservation Protocol) is used with MPLS (Multiprotocol Label Switching) for traffic engineering. It reserves the necessary resources (such as bandwidth) along the path of the MPLS traffic engineering tunnel. This allows the network to ensure that sufficient resources are available for specific traffic flows, improving network performance and ensuring quality of service (QoS).
